beer.beer_description:
We brought out Junction Ale as our first anniversary ale. Being close to the UK’s busiest railway station I decided people needed another reason to go ‘Up the Junction’ and Junction Ale was born. In style it is very different to Wandle and was brewed in tribute to a good friend of mine who often complains about ‘too much flowery aromas in beers these days!’ 

Junction is brewed as a traditional English bitter, using only English hop varieties, lots of crystal malt and a touch of roasted barley to give it an inviting auburn colour. Great with a steak pie or a roast dinner, Junction is a fine compliment to Wandle Ale, but loses none of its drinkability. Just treat it with a bit of respect, at 4.5% it is a little bit stronger than Wandle.

Just treat it with a bit of respect, at 4.5% it is a little bit stronger than Wandle.

items.checkin_comment: Ticking off the pubs. Half. Amber-orange colour, a bit of haze, no head. No aroma. Dilute malt taste, fruity core, quite nutty. Mildly bitter finish. Unusually it's probably served a touch too warm.

user.bio: Always try what's new. Sours, ciders, malty styles, low-alc. Bottle shops, festivals, pubs.

items.badge_description: Dispensed traditionally by hand pump, cask beers are best served at 55°F. This temperature allows all of the flavor nuances to emerge and permits appreciation of the often unfiltered texture. That's 90 checkins with the serving style of Cask! Try 5 more for Level 19!

items.badge_description: Dispensed traditionally by hand pump, cask beers are best served at 55°F. This temperature allows all of the flavor nuances to emerge and permits appreciation of the often unfiltered texture. That's 25 checkins with the serving style of Cask! Try 5 more for Level 6!

While a pint of traditional English ale will always remain a staple, the craft beer scene in England, much like the rest of the world, has continued to grow at a rapid rate! That's 45 different beers from a brewery from England! Try 5 more for Level 10!
